subjects.name: Mathematics
subjects.description: Study of numbers, quantity, and space

topics.name: Differential Equations
topics.description: Introduction to differential equations

questions.text: Solve the differential equation: dy/dx = 2x.
questions.answer: y = x^2 + C, where C is the constant of integration.

questions.text: Find the particular solution of the differential equation: dy/dx = x^2, y(0) = 1.
Verify if the function y = e^(2x) is a solution to the differential equation dy/dx = 2e^(2x).
Solve the first-order linear differential equation: (x + 1)y' - 2y = 4.
Use separation of variables to solve the differential equation: (y^2 + 1)dy/dx = 2x.
questions.answer: y = tan(x + C), where C is the constant of integration.

questions.text: Find the solution to the Bernoulli differential equation: y' - y = 2y^3.
questions.answer: y = (1/(1 - C*e^(2x)))^(1/2), where C is the constant of integration.

questions.text: Determine the interval on which the solution to the differential equation is guaranteed to exist: y' = y^2, y(0) = 1.
Apply the method of undetermined coefficients to solve the differential equation: y'' - y = e^x.
questions.answer: y = Ae^x + Be^(-x) + 1/2*x*e^x, where A and B are constants.

questions.text: Solve the system of differential equations: dx/dt = x + y, dy/dt = x - y.
questions.answer: x(t) = C1*cos(t) + C2*sin(t), y(t) = C1*sin(t) - C2*cos(t), where C1 and C2 are constants.

questions.text: Evaluate the Laplace transform of the function f(t) = 3e^(2t) - 4sin(3t).

topics.name: Calculus
topics.description: Fundamental principles of calculus

questions.text: Find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 1.
Calculate the integral: ∫(2x + 5)dx.
questions.answer: x^2 + 5x + C, where C is the constant of integration.

questions.text: Determine the critical points of the function g(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 9x.
Evaluate the limit: lim(x → 2) (x^2 - 4) / (x - 2).
Find the local minimum and maximum values of the function h(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 9x.
questions.answer: Local minimum at x = -√3, local maximum at x = 3.

questions.text: Compute the derivative of the natural logarithm function: d/dx(ln(x)).
Solve the differential equation dy/dx = 2x, given y(0) = 1.
Determine the intervals where the function f(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 5 is increasing or decreasing.
Find the absolute maximum and minimum values of the function k(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 + 2x on the interval [0, 3].
questions.answer: Absolute maximum at x = 0, absolute minimum at x = 2.

questions.text: Calculate the area under the curve y = x^2 from x = 1 to x = 3.
questions.answer: The area is 6/3 units^2 or 2 square units.

topics.name: Linear Algebra
topics.description: Study of linear systems and vector spaces

questions.text: Given the matrices A = [[1, 2], [3, 4]] and B = [[5, 6], [7, 8]], find the sum A + B.
Find the determinant of the matrix C = [[-2, 1], [4, -3]].
Given the matrix D = [[2, 0, -1], [1, 3, 2], [4, 5, 6]], find its inverse.
Solve the system of linear equations: 2x + 3y = 7, 4x - y = 6.
Find the eigenvalues of the matrix E = [[3, 1], [2, 4]].
Compute the cross product of vectors u = [2, -1, 3] and v = [4, 5, 1].
Determine if the vectors w = [1, 2, -3] and z = [2, 4, -6] are linearly dependent or independent.
Find the rank of the matrix F = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8, 9]].
Given the vector space V = {v1, v2, v3} with v1 = [1, 0, -1], v2 = [0, 1, 2], v3 = [-1, 2, 3], determine if it forms a basis for R^3.
questions.answer: Yes, it forms a basis for R^3.

questions.text: Verify if the transformation T: R^2 → R^2 defined by T(x, y) = (2x + y, 3x - y) is linear.

topics.name: Number Theory
topics.description: Properties and relationships of numbers

topics.name: Probability Theory
topics.description: Understanding probability distributions

topics.name: Geometry
topics.description: Properties of shapes and spaces

topics.name: Statistics
topics.description: Analyzing and interpreting data

topics.name: Combinatorics
topics.description: Counting and arranging objects

topics.name: Abstract Algebra
topics.description: Algebraic structures and their properties

topics.name: Mathematical Logic
topics.description: Study of logical principles in mathematics

subjects.name: Physics
subjects.description: Study of matter, energy, and the fundamental forces of nature

topics.name: Mechanics
topics.description: Study of motion and forces

questions.text: A car accelerates uniformly from rest to a speed of 30 m/s in 10 seconds. Calculate the acceleration of the car.
A ball is thrown vertically upward with an initial velocity of 20 m/s. How high does the ball go? (Neglect air resistance.)
A force of 50 N is applied to a 10 kg object. What is the acceleration of the object?
Two forces, 30 N and 40 N, act at an angle of 60 degrees to each other. Find the resultant force.
questions.answer: Resultant force = 50 N at an angle of 36.87 degrees.

questions.text: A 500 kg car is moving with a velocity of 20 m/s. Calculate the kinetic energy of the car.
If an object experiences a net force of 100 N and accelerates at 5 m/s^2, what is its mass?
A block of mass 2 kg is placed on an inclined plane with an angle of 30 degrees. Determine the gravitational force component parallel to the incline.
A projectile is launched with an initial velocity of 40 m/s at an angle of 30 degrees to the horizontal. Calculate the maximum height reached by the projectile.
A spring with a force constant of 200 N/m is compressed by 0.2 meters. Calculate the potential energy stored in the spring.
A 300 kg cart is moving on a horizontal surface with a velocity of 5 m/s. If the frictional force is 50 N, what is the net force acting on the cart?
questions.answer: Net force = 0 N (assuming no other forces).

topics.name: Thermodynamics
topics.description: Understanding heat and energy transfer

questions.text: If 500 J of heat is added to a system, and the system does 200 J of work, what is the change in internal energy?
questions.answer: Change in internal energy = 300 J (Q - W).

questions.text: A gas expands from a volume of 2 L to 6 L against a constant external pressure of 3 atm. Calculate the work done by the gas.
Define the First Law of Thermodynamics and provide an equation representing it.
questions.answer: First Law: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. Equation: ΔU = Q - W.

questions.text: A container of gas undergoes an isothermal process. If 1500 J of heat is added, what is the work done by the gas?
questions.answer: Work done = 1500 J (for an isothermal process).

questions.text: If the internal energy of a system decreases by 200 J and 150 J of work is done on the system, what is the heat exchanged?
A heat engine absorbs 800 J of heat and does 300 J of work. What is the efficiency of the heat engine?
State the second law of thermodynamics and explain it in the context of entropy.
questions.answer: Second Law: Entropy of an isolated system tends to increase over time. Entropy change is ΔS = Q/T.

questions.text: A refrigerator absorbs 200 J of heat from the inside and rejects 50 J of heat to the surroundings. What is the net work done by the refrigerator?
questions.answer: Net work done = 150 J (Net work = Qc - Qh).

questions.text: Define the term 'adiabatic process' in thermodynamics.
questions.answer: An adiabatic process is one in which no heat is exchanged with the surroundings (Q = 0).

questions.text: A gas undergoes an isochoric process. If 300 J of heat is added, what is the change in internal energy?
questions.answer: Change in internal energy = 300 J (for an isochoric process).

topics.name: Electricity and Magnetism
topics.description: Principles of electric and magnetic fields

questions.text: A circuit has a resistance of 20 ohms and a current of 2 A. Calculate the voltage across the circuit.
Two point charges, +Q and -Q, are separated by a distance 'd'. Calculate the electric potential energy between them.
questions.answer: Electric potential energy = kQ^2/d, where k is Coulomb's constant.

questions.text: If a wire carries a current of 4 A and is perpendicular to a magnetic field of 0.5 T, what is the force experienced by the wire?
questions.answer: Force = 2 N (Force = BIL, where B is the magnetic field, I is the current, and L is the length of the wire).

questions.text: Define electric potential and provide the formula relating it to electric field and distance.
A capacitor with a capacitance of 10 μF is connected to a 12 V battery. Calculate the charge stored on the capacitor.
questions.answer: Charge = 120 μC (Q = CV, where C is the capacitance and V is the voltage).

questions.text: An electron moves with a velocity of 3 x 10^6 m/s perpendicular to a magnetic field of 0.4 T. What is the magnetic force acting on the electron?
questions.answer: Magnetic force = 1.2 x 10^(-12) N (F = qvB, where q is the charge, v is the velocity, and B is the magnetic field).

questions.text: A coil with 100 turns and an area of 0.02 m^2 is placed in a magnetic field of 0.1 T. Calculate the induced emf if the coil rotates at a rate of 50 Hz.
questions.answer: Induced emf = 100 V (Emf = NABω, where N is the number of turns, A is the area, B is the magnetic field, and ω is the angular frequency).

questions.text: Two resistors of 4 ohms and 6 ohms are connected in series. What is the equivalent resistance of the combination?
questions.answer: Equivalent resistance = 10 ohms (For resistors in series, Req = R1 + R2).

questions.text: In a parallel circuit, if the voltage across each resistor is 12 V and the resistances are 8 ohms and 16 ohms, calculate the total current.
questions.answer: Total current = 1.5 A (For resistors in parallel, 1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2).

questions.text: A solenoid has 500 turns and carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field inside the solenoid.
questions.answer: Magnetic field = 0.002 T (B = μ₀nI, where μ₀ is the permeability of free space, n is the number of turns per unit length, and I is the current).

topics.name: Quantum Mechanics
topics.description: Behavior of matter and energy at the smallest scales

topics.name: Optics
topics.description: Study of light and its interactions with matter

topics.description: Properties and behavior of atomic nuclei

topics.description: Theory of space, time, and gravity

subjects.name: Chemistry
subjects.description: Study of the composition, structure, properties, and change of matter

topics.name: Inorganic Chemistry
topics.description: Properties and behavior of inorganic compounds

questions.text: Calculate the molar mass of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).
If 2 moles of hydrogen react with 1 mole of oxygen to form water, what is the limiting reactant?
Balance the chemical equation: Fe2O3 + CO → Fe + CO2.
Calculate the pH of a solution with a hydrogen ion concentration of 1 x 10^(-9) M.
A sample of gas occupies 4 L at 27°C. If the temperature is increased to 77°C, what is the new volume (at constant pressure)?
Determine the oxidation state of sulfur in H2SO4.
How many moles of NaCl are present in 250 mL of a 0.5 M solution?
Write the electron configuration for the element nitrogen (N).
If a reaction has a rate constant of 0.02 s^(-1), what is the half-life of the reaction?
Balance the chemical equation: NH4NO3 → N2O + H2O.

topics.name: Organic Chemistry
topics.description: Study of carbon-containing compounds

questions.text: Draw the structural formula for ethanol (C2H5OH).
What is the IUPAC name for the following compound: CH3CH2COOH?
If 2-bromopropane reacts with sodium ethoxide, what is the major product?
Write the reaction mechanism for the bromination of ethane.
Calculate the degree of unsaturation for a compound with the molecular formula C8H10.
Identify the functional group in the compound CH3CHO.
Draw the resonance structures for the nitrate ion (NO3-).
If a reaction has a rate constant of 0.05 s^(-1), what is the half-life of the reaction?
What is the major product in the dehydration of 2-methylcyclohexanol?
Write the reaction mechanism for the hydrolysis of an ester.

topics.name: Physical Chemistry
topics.description: Understanding the physical principles of chemical systems

questions.text: Calculate the work done when 2 moles of a gas expand isothermally at 300 K against a constant pressure of 1 atm.
questions.answer: Work done = -RTln(V2/V1), where R is the ideal gas constant.

questions.text: If a gas occupies 10 L at 25°C and 1 atm, what is the density of the gas in g/L?
What is the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of methane (CH4)?
If a reaction has a rate constant of 0.02 s^(-1), what is the half-life of the reaction?
Calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for a reaction where ΔH = 50 kJ/mol and ΔS = 120 J/(mol·K) at 300 K.
Define the term 'equilibrium constant' (Kc) in the context of a chemical reaction.
What is the Nernst equation, and how is it used to calculate the cell potential?
questions.answer: Nernst equation: E = E° - (RT/nF) * ln(Q), where E is the cell potential, R is the ideal gas constant, T is the temperature, n is the number of moles of electrons transferred, F is Faraday's constant, and Q is the reaction quotient.

questions.text: Calculate the pH of a 0.01 M hydrochloric acid solution.
Derive the expression for the ideal gas law (PV = nRT).
questions.answer: Derived from the combined gas law and ideal gas equation.

questions.text: Explain the concept of entropy in thermodynamics.
questions.answer: Entropy is a measure of the disorder or randomness of a system. ΔS = Q/T.

topics.name: Analytical Chemistry
topics.description: Techniques for analyzing and characterizing substances

topics.name: Biochemistry
topics.description: Chemical processes within and related to living organisms

topics.description: Study of polymers and macromolecules

topics.description: Chemistry of the environment and pollution

topics.name: Industrial Chemistry
topics.description: Chemical processes in industrial production

topics.name: Medicinal Chemistry
topics.description: Design and synthesis of pharmaceutical agents
